awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a femtosecond angle-resolved electron spectroscopy system for mapping the 3D electronic structures and responses of functional materials and nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to control and engineer complex materials and nanostructures is essential for enabling an array of technologies including: solar-energy harvesting, solar to fuel conversion, heat recovery, and the development of novel photoactive nanostructured materials and nanoelectronics devices used in computing and internet infrastructure. This project will overcome widely recognized major bottlenecks to progress by addressing the scarcity of experimental data on the changes of local properties in these functional materials or devices.  This is enabled by using innovative accelerator-based approaches to manipulate the probe's dynamical properties to significantly enhance the intensity and time-resolution of an ultrafast electron probe system.   The high-throughput of the present system is the ideal probe for unveiling transient photochemical processes due to its high sensitivity to charge states and its more direct accesses to local electronic structures and electron dynamics for pinpointing the origins of these local, transient electronic processes.  Furthermore, the present system advantageously provides three-dimensional spectroscopy by high-energy beams that penetrate the bulk of samples and the ability to sample large energy dispersion and momentum distributions.  These new capabilities are also relevant to understanding an array of complex materials issues of broad interest, including studies of high-temperature superconductors, phase transitions, and novel electronic switching devices. Scientific and technological progress will be enabled by a unique team of experts in accelerator and beam physics, radiofrequency cavity design and construction, femtosecond (one quadrillionth, or one millionth of one billionth, of a second) laser and electron beam technologies, and theoretical modeling for the development of this unique ultrahigh speed electron beam system. The outcome of this MRI will be potentially transformative for addressing Grand Challenge Problems in nanoscience and nanotechnology that are critical to the industrial and applied sector, in areas ranging from catalysis to photovoltaics and material synthesis. We envision that the successful development of such a technology will lead to a new generation of electron-based ultrafast spectroscopy systems that are economical enough to be widely replicated in individual industry or university-based laboratories .

A novel ultrafast high-brightness electron spectrometer system will be designed and implemented to achieve high sensitivity and combined high momentum-energy resolution through innovative active energy compression technology to preserve the throughput of the femtosecond photo-activated electron beam. The new system, a prototype ultrafast angle-resolved electron spectroscopy system, will be the first of its kind to provide element-sensitive spectroscopic imaging of three-dimensional electronic structures in complex and nanostructured materials at ultrafast timescales. The new capabilities will provide needed high throughput, and access to bulk crystalline materials. Significantly broader reach in energy scales will be available, covering the entire Brillouin Zone of quantum and complex materials with three-dimensional electronic structures, thus providing a more universal method than existing approaches.  It is also targeted to substantially enhance the temporal-momentum resolution and throughput of electron-based spectroscopy systems to ultimately allow studies of individual nanostructures and motifs. The resulting spectrometer will be well-suited for characterizing; radiation effects in materials, defects, and photo-responses in plasmonic and photovoltaic nanostructures; phase transitions of superconductors and complex, strongly correlated electron materials; and exploring novel phases of matter in extreme environments. Scientific and technological progress will be enabled by a unique team of experts in accelerator and beam physics, radiofrequency cavity design and construction, femtosecond laser and electron beam technologies, and theoretical modeling for the development of this unique femtosecond electron beam system. The outcome of this MRI will be potentially transformative for investigating ultrafast physical, chemical and materials electronic processes to understand and identify the emerging and functional properties of complex, nanostructured materials and devices for addressing Grand Challenge Problems in condensed matter physics, materials and chemistry. Such a capability is also of interest to the industrial and applied sector, in areas ranging from catalysis to photovoltaics and material synthesis. It is envisioned that the successful development of such a technology will lead to a new generation of electron-based ultrafast spectroscopy systems that are economical enough to be widely replicated in individual industrial or university-based laboratories for ultrafast materials research.

Overview:

The purpose of this NSF MRI was to develop a new ultrafast electron beamline for electron imaging and spectroscopy based on mini-RF-accelerator technologies and incorporating them into a TEM electron optical system. TEM is a powerful materials characterization tool that offers nanoscale information on a wide range of materials and devices and the relevant technologies have been crucial for materials research. However, TEM systems traditionally come with a very limited time resolution. Recent efforts in upgrading the TEM with ultrashort time resolution encountered dauting roadblocks presented by the space-charge effect, leading to a significant trade-off between the resolution and the sensitivity. This MRI proposed a revolutionary solution to address this limiting drawback by incorporating active time and energy compression technologies to drive the high-intensity electron pulses into coherent probes without sacrificing resolutions. To translate the novel ultrafast beamline concepts into a working prototype, the MRI team took three interwoven approaches to push the technological and scientific frontiers.  On optimizing the probe beam delivery, foundational studies of beam dynamics at the space-charge limit were made through joint theory-experiment efforts. On perfecting the core engine driving the system performance using the mini-RF-accelerator devices, the team collaborated with the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams to develop multilevel RF controllers to reduce the phase noises and improved the precision of the RF device by one order of magnitude.  On the beamline construction, the team reverse-engineered a conventional TEM and incorporated all the core optical components for achieving multimodalities mediated by the RF devices.

 

Technical merits:

On advancing a unique instrument concept, the MRI team delivered on improved performance based on new core compression concept. Specially, the team clearly demonstrated in practical settings a high degree of manipulability for the electron pulses operating at the space-charge limit to result in better resolutions. For example, in the MRI facility one now routinely utilized large numbers of electrons (105 to 107) in a single pulse and compressed the pulse temporally to reach ~ 100 fs resolution or ~ 1eV for the respective ultrafast measurements. Since here one actively manipulates the entire phase-space of electron pulses into resolution windows, complementary in situ spectroscopic and imaging measurements through adjusting the optical arrangements are achieved without slicing off significant part of the beam to preserve a high signal strength.  On delivering a functional scientific instrument, we have perfected the core engine, i.e., the mini-RF accelerator system (resonance cavity and the associated control electronics). As a result, by the end of the MRI project, we were able to establish a truly "one of a kind" working prototype for investigating the ultrafast dynamics in materials. In particular here the team demonstrated that the conventional TEM optical system can be meshed with the RF devices and through momentum-selection of scattered electrons assembled a genuinely multimodal instrument in studying material transformations, as illustrated in Figure 1. Here the team investigated the transient reactions of the quantum materials following initial swift change of the fundamental interactions by way of femtosecond laser initiations. Ultrafast MRI facility provided the exquisite opportunity to "watch" the emergence of novel functionalities [e.g., insulator-to-metal transitions coupled with subtle structural changes].   Figure 1 shows the transient dynamics pertaining to the functional state evolution from the microscopic (angstrom and fs) dimensions to the macroscopic (nm and ns) scales with several complementary perspectives under the same platform: the ultrafast imaging monitored the system-wide morphological state; the coherent scattering probed the transient ordering from angstroms to nanometers; and the incoherent and inelastically scattered electron tracked the emergence of metallicity across the entire time.

Broader impacts:

The MRI development trained undergraduate, REU, graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars at Michigan State University by presenting them various opportunities to develop professional skills over the entire developmental process involving design, implementation, and scientific application stages. This MRI team taught in US Particle Physics School (USPAS), including designing a new curriculum on femtosecond electron sources for ultrafast sciences. The MRI team also involved in the community building and organized international conferences on relevant multidisciplinary areas of sciences and technologies, such as FEIS workshops and PIPT conferences.  With growing awareness of the new technological concepts and scientific opportunities they enable, these activities provided platforms for cross-fertilization in future development. One example is PIPT7 held virtually in 2021 with themes on multimodal techniques and ultrafast material phase transitions. It is worth noting that PIPT7 in particular attracted a large number of graduate students and postdocs to participate; see Figure 2. This MRI project also resulted in the first step of commercialization with the award of a US patent on ultrafast electron spectroscopy. Furthermore, the team participated a (DOE) SBIR grant with a local business in designing small scale RF devices to turn them into an insertable module to power the conventional TEM with better temporal and energy resolutions.
